>

erated from two data elements -
>the html template and the data also visibl=
e via the other resource.
>

Yet also unmistakably what is meant by "repres=
entation".

Not two, multiple.  What I've implemented is XSLTC, here's an o=
versimplified overview, imagine each ;view=3D option as *.xsl, and realize =
they're all transforming the same Atom document and that the menu links are=
 implemented in the XSLT file:

/resource;view=3Dtext  <-- text-only versio=
n of the resource
/resource;view=3Dprint  <-- content (including images) on=
ly no menus
/resource;view=3Dedit  <-- like the print view except in a <for=
m>

Those three respond 200 OK, as they serve both as alternate representat=
ions and as resources in their own right.  Back functionality preserved.  O=
utput is HTML 4.01 but with no DOCTYPE, except for ;view=3Dedit which uses =
the markup language most compatible with the client based on content negoti=
ation, as are these options:

/resource;view=3Dmobile  <-- XHTML Basic 1.1
=
/resource;view=3Dxhtml  <-- XHTML 1.1
/resource;view=3Dhtml  <-- HTML 4.01
=

These are determined by content negotiation, IE and anything else not grok=
king 'application/xhtml+xml' gets HTML markup and all the frivolous class a=
ttributes required for backwards CSS compatibility with IE < 7, and a silly=
 "IE Conditional Comment" to give IE >=3D 7 the same CSS as other modern br=
owsers, which of course get the XHTML 1.1 _representation_ of the site.

A =
Firefox user can append ;view=3Dhtml to any /resource on my system and view=
 the HTML 4.01 alternate representation of the content, but they'll be 303-=
redirected back to /resource to set it (as I explained in my treatise, "Rep=
resentational Cookies").  An IE user can select ;view=3Dxhtml but they'll g=
et a dialog box asking how they want to save the unknown 'application/octet=
-stream'.

I extended my content-negotiation-override mechanism to provide =
the text-only, print and edit representations but yes, they're all also res=
ources.  I call the result a Representation Management System, though, sinc=
e the purpose is to allow a visitor to a website to select a different repr=
esentation suited to their needs.

>
>Why not allow PUT to the html templat=
e portion of that 'editor' resource?
>What would happen if you did?
>

Why =
not?  Enough complexity already with this system.  ;)  Also, it doesn't mak=
e sense to me.  The editor is provided to edit the resource, allowing PUT t=
o that editor resource would presumably be to change what <textarea> replac=
ement editor it links to, or somesuch.

Allowing PUT to the editor document=
 rather than the /resource could also be a means to allow editing of the ge=
nerated menu links for the /resource, overriding anything automatically gen=
erated, allowing the webmaster to "hide" a page from public view.  Just som=
e thoughts.

-Eric
